div.l: That dwelled in the halle which I sey
Testyf thei were ⁊and lusty for to pley
And only for hur merthes ⁊and hur reuelrye
Vpon the warteyne bisily thei crye
To yeue hem leue but a litel stounde
To go to mylle ⁊and sene hur corn y grounde
And hardely thei durst yeue hur necke
The myller shulde not stele him self a pecke
Of corn̄ ne bi sleyghte ne bi fors hem reue
And at the laste this wardeyne yaf hem leue
Iohn hight that on ⁊and Alleyne hight that other
Of oo town were thei born̄ that hight strother
Fer in the north I can not telle where
This Aleyne maketh al redy his gere
And on an hors the sak casteth a non
Forth goth Aleyne ⁊and forth goth Iohn
Wᵗith good swerd ⁊and bokeler bi hur syde
Iohn knewe the wey him nedeth no gyde
And at the mylle the sak a doıı̄un he sleythseythleyth
Aleyne spak furst al heyle symond he seyth
How fareth thi feyre doughter ⁊and thi wyf
Aleyne wel come ꝙquod symkyn bi my lyf
And Iohn also now what do ye here
¶ Bigod ꝙquod Iohn symond for nede hath no pere
Him bihoueth to serue hīm self that hath no swayne
Or elles he is a fole as clerkes sayne
Oure maıı̄unciple I hope he wol be ded
So worcheth ay the anguysh in his hed
And ther fore am come ⁊and eke Aleyne
To grynde oure corn̄ ⁊and brynge hit hom a yeyne
I pray you spede we henne as tyte as ye may
Hit shal be do ꝙquod symkyn bi my fay
